reviewText: After the success of the ABC's daytime soap Dark Shadows, the creator Dan Curtis directed a darker version from the script written by Sam Hall and Gordon Russell and produced by MGM back in 1970. The script was based on the popular Barnabas storyline and starred the original cast such as Jonathan Frid, Grayson Hall, Kathryn Leigh Scott, David Henesy, and Roger Davis. The movie was shot in six weeks with a budget of $750,000, which is now considered a low-budget.The movie uses an altered version of the Barnabas plot. The recently fired handyman Willie Loomis visit's the Collins' family Old House in an attempt to steal rare jewels, but instead he unleashes the vampire cursed Barnabas from his 150-year confinement. Using his vampire powers, Barnabas makes Willie his slave. Barnabas wastes no time and introduces his self to the Collins family as a cousin to England.Barnabas meets the young governess, Maggie Evans, who looks exactly like his lost-love Josette. While during this time, Barnabas turns Carolyn, whom is later staked by Professor T. Eliot Stokes.The family doctor, Julia Hoffman, examines the blood of the victims and, for some unknown reason, knows that vampirism is behind the deaths. She soon realizes that Barnabas is a vampire and she offers to cure him. Barnabas accepts the offer. For a short time he is cured and begins to romance Maggie Evans.Julia falls for Barnabas and becomes jealous of Maggie, resulting in Barnabas being given an overdose of the cure, which shows his true age to Maggie. With his true identity exposed, Barnabas must kill the entire Collins family and anyone else that becomes between Maggie and him.House of Dark Shadows is an edgier, bloodier version of the campy daytime soap, and, in my opinion, one of the creepiest vampire movies every made. The sets have a more gothic vibe than the series did. Sadly, the movie has never been released on DVD, but rumor has it that it'll be released by Warner Bros. later in 2012. For those of you that can't wait, there is an older version on VHS which you can sometimes find on Ebay or Amazon.com for sale. Occasionally, TCM and Chiller air House of Dark Shadows, along with the sequel Night of Dark Shadows.

reviewText: I was too young to remember "Dark Shadows" when it was serialized between 1966-71.  My best friend saw the repeats on the Sci-Fi channel and is a huge fan. reviewText: This 1970 treat is actually one of the first films I had hoped to review at Amazon. I loved this film from the time it was new, before the silly post-1970s vampire/werewolf flicks, and other pathetic attempts at portraying anything Goth on film. HOUSE OF DARK SHADOWS not only takes me back to a better time, every time, but it reminds me of what Gothic horror and romance was really meant to be.Directed by creator and tv-series-producer Dan Curtis, HOUSE OF DARK SHADOWS is perhaps THE singular story of Barnabas Collins (the immortal Canadian Jonathan Frid), told for the first time in a feature-length film and without the distraction of werewolf Quentin.Here the dopey, intrusive dolt Willie (the great John Karlen, here very young) releases Barnabas Collins from his chained-up coffin, where Barnabas has been imprisoned I think since 1795. Though Curtis takes the high road and we do not see Barnabas at first, well, old-time hardcore fans know!In one of the most striking and compelling scenes I have ever witnessed, Barnabas makes his way to the Collinwood mansion. Now recall, this is supposed to be Collinsport, Maine--Bangor was their actual stand-in location and it is lovely. However, this scene is at night, and the camera is from Barnabas' view. When he reaches the main door and rings the doorbell, when he is allowed to enter and introduces himself, it is all through his 175-year-old eyes. When he reaches out with his beringed finger to press the C key on the organ, it still sends chills of glee up my spine.Recognizing their hitherto unknown cousin from England, as Barnabas is passing himself, they even remark on his cane and the ring, clearly visible in the Maine family portrait of the "first" Barnabas. Naturally there is vampire havoc , and I must say Curtis has to be enshrined with all other A-grade vampire filmmakers. The way he approached this, which should have been called "Barnabas' Story", has inspired over five generations of movie makers and fans alike.The storyline, if you do not know it, is too fun (and intricate) for me to reveal. The actors are brilliant (a luxury they never had on tv) and in fact they inspired a lot of British tv and film for many decades. All of them are Shakespearian actors, and some were English trained (very common in the 1960s and 1970s). Jonathan Frid is mighty, powerful and frightening, yet he is also pathetically human and in pain. There was no actor at the time who could have done this role...I've often imagined Leonard Nimoy in the role and it makes me laugh. I would never laugh at Spock!In any case, enough cannot be said about Barnabas Collins as created by Jonathan Frid. In his day, he was world-famous, and I recall a fan symposium in which Frid said he had vacationed in Mexico. While there, everyone called him "Barnabas" because they all knew him. Frid said he loved the way "Barnabas" is pronounced in Spanish, and it happens by a very bizarre coincidence to be one of my middle names.Get this gem, even though IT OUGHT TO BE ON DVD by now. You will never regret it, and though it is dated and at certain moments shabby, it only adds to the genuine Gothic horror. And no "Dark Shadows" fan can be without it.UPDATE: I wanted all fans to read my newest review, but do not wish to replace my old review. So here you go:HOUSE OF DARK SHADOWS (writ., prod., dir. Dan Curtis, 1970, 97 minutes) is the decades-ahead-of-its-time backstory of Barnabas Collins, the most popular and iconic vampire in vampire history. With the incredible Gothic atmosphere (I love to call this cinematic achievement "atmosfear"), with its understated classic horror, with its humanity and profound lessons, DARK SHADOWS is a must. Especially now when we are all being threatened by a Tim Burton spoof remake starring Johnny Depp.Yes, this film extrapolates the backstory from the old daytime soap opera - but who cares, it's fun! And this is one of the finest vampire films ever made.Here, the unfortunate Willy (the immortal John Karlen) finds Barnabas Collins' coffin and looses him on what I always assumed is the city of Bangor, Maine. After Willy gets him adjusted and up-to-date, Barnabas wheedles his way back to Collinwood and into the arms of his family. They accept him fully, as he introduces himself as a cousin from England. His knowledge of the family and the grounds is startling, and his portrait - well, it is him after all!The camera work, which turns out to be from Barnabas' viewpoint as he approaches the front door of Collinwood, is revolutionary. reviewText: Horror film "scholars" have always been split on the merits of HOUSE OF DARK SHADOWS; some consider it a cheesy collection of soap opera characters and contrived situations, others appreciate the film's cinematic style and overall vitality, especially during a period was Hammer was giving us embarrassments like THE SCARS OF DRACULA.  I've always loved HOUSE, goofy soap opera elements be damned.  Every single shot in this movie is carefully composed, every set-up creative and inspired.  Frid breaks new ground as a tortured, Byronic vampire, and the rest of the cast, framed and photographed with aggressive imagination, comes off just fine.  Sure, Julia's sudden "love" for Barnabas is ludicrous, but most of this movie is surprisingly stylish, with slo-mo blood kills, Orson Welles-style dissolves, incredible angles and camera moves, expressive dark cinematography (this really IS a house of dark shadows!), fabulous real locations instead of crummy sets, and Dick Smith's make-up creations making up for any script shortcomings.  Fans should be very pleased with this new Blu-ray edition, which presents the film in 1.85 widescreen, preserving Curtis' grand compositions (sorry, but "zooming up" the TCM print does not produce the same results).  Yep, it's a shame that there are no extras (not to mention the much-discussed restored footage we never got), but the movie itself is more than worth the purchase.  Highly recommended!

reviewText: Largely because it was based on a cult daytime seriel, House of Dark Shadows has always been underrated and often unfairly dismissed as just one last attempt to exploit the show's then-waning popularity.  As well, House of Dark Shadows came out at a time when the vampire film was having a minor revival and as such, it is often simply lumped together with the likes of Count Yorga or Blacula and forgotten.  This is unfortunate because, when watched with an unbiased, open mind, House of Dark Shadows is revealed to be one of the best horror films of the '70s, an original work that -- if indeed it was created mostly to cash in on a tv show in decline -- manages to both improve on the show and to stand along as its own seperate, highly satisfying terms.It is true that the film's plot is basically a retelling of the first few years of the tv show.  Petty criminal Willie Loomis  accidentally releases 200 year-old vampire Barnabas Collins who proceeds to reacquaint himself with the modern day Collins family, all the while pining for his lost love Josette and feeding on random victims during the night. A local doctor, Julia Hoffman, discovers that Barnabas is a vampire, and persuades him to let her try to cure him. When he discovers what he believes to be Josette's modern day incarnation in the form of Maggie Evans, a jealous Hoffman spikes his cure which leads to a lot of a mayhem, a lot of blood, and most of the cast (all playing versions of their beloved TV characters) dead.That's where the movie breaks off from the TV show and sets up its own identity. Whereas on the television show, Barnabas was a tortured hero out of Wuthering Heights, in the film he is pure evil, an indiscriminate killer who -- by the bloody end -- has managed to wipe out almost all the remaining members of his family.  For fans of the TV show, it provides quite a shock to see such familiar characters struck down.  However, all of the actors give sympathetic, likeable performances.  Nobody can be dismissed as just doing "television" work and even if you have no background with the show, its hard not to feel pained as they all meet their end.  In the end, this helps to create one of the most truly dark horror films I have ever seen.As said before, the acting is far better than the show's reputation might lead some to guess.  By most reports, the actors were getting tired of the show by the time the film was shot and as a result, they seem to get an extra jolt of energy from the chance to kill each other off.  Special mention should be made of John Karlen, whose jittery Loomis is one of the film's highlights and veteran character actor Thayer David is a strong Van Helsing-type as Prof. Stokes.  As Barnabas, Jonathan Frid -- whose disdain for the TV show is well documented -- is a terrifyingly evil presence.  For fans of the show, one of the film's joys is a chance to see actors who never got to do much on the television show actually sink their teeth (or fangs) into the film's juicier roles and pull them off far better than anyone could have guessed.  Roger Davis -- who always seemed to be getting killed on the show -- is a strong, sympathetic hero while Elizabeth Barrett makes for a sexy vampire.  (Her final battle with the film's vampire hunters is one of the film's most suspenseful -- and bloody -- moments.)The film is well directed by Dan Curtis who makes a point of not using any of the familiar locations from the TV series but instead totally reimagines the world of Dark Shadows.  Working with a low budget, he still pulls off several atmospheric scenes and, most importantly, never allows the story to drag or the action to cease.  The film is far more graphic than anything ever seen on the television show and the film's ending is almost disturbingly intense.  This is a film that will surprise, frighten, and delight fans and non-fans of the show alike.
summary: One of the best vampire films of all time

reviewText: To those of you spending your days bewitched by the misadventures of Tabitha and Timmy on "Passions," there are those of us who are here to remind you of "Dark Shadows," the cult soap opera hit that ran from 1966-71.  The Gothic soap was floundering in the ratings when the character of vampire Barnabas Collins (Jonathan Frid) was introduced.  Producer/Director Dan Curtis provided this 1970 introduction to the wonderful world of "Dark Shadows," so late comers could get up to speed.  Barnabas is freed from his crypt after nearly 200 years by a thief stealing treasure and returns to the family home Collinwood pretending to be a distant English cousin who just happens to be named for the infamous "ancestor."  Barnabas discovers that the family governess, Maggie Evans (Kathryn Leigh Scott) is the spitting image of his former love Josette, who killed herself when she learned he had become a vampire.  Meanwhile, the family physician Dr. Julia Hoffman (Grayson Hall) learns of Barnabas' true identity and develops a treatment that will reverse the curse.  Able to walk in daylight again, Barnabas plans on marrying Maggie.  Unfortunately, Dr. Hoffman has fallen in love with Barnabas and sabotges the treatments, which results in quite a bloodbath."House of Dark Shadows" certainly stands on its own if you have never seen the soap opera, although the effort to give everyone in the cast some screen time does get in the way from time to time.  For those who remember the show, it is nice to see Louis Edmonds, Nancy Barrett, Joan Benett and the others again.  The script by Sam Hall and Gordon Russell is actually quite innovative, coming up with some new twists for the love triangle while working in notions of reincarnation and scientific approaches to curing vampirism.  At the heart of the film is Frid's portrayal of Barnabas Collins, which offers considerably more depth to the character than we were getting at the time from Christopher Lee's Dracula in all those Hammer films.
summary: Before there was "Passions," there was "Dark Shadows"!

reviewText: House of Dark Shadows was made just as the televised soap opera version was coming to an end on television. The film did exceptionally well despite the fact that the soap opera's audience was beginning to drop off.The film, in effect, retold the opening passages of the first season scripts. It's the first story and the best - the unleashing of 200 year old Barnabas Collins from the family tomb into the present day life at Collingswood.Dark Shadows is primarily remembered because of Barnabas Collins- and more importantly because of Jonathan Frid's portrayal of him. He mesmerized with this feeling he gave of what this `creature' was feeling, reawakening to present day, to a new generation of the family, and to the self loathing and lust he felt for what he was: a vampire. None of that has ever been an easy feat to perform in films like these and for my money, if anyone really pulled out the stops and played it well, it was Jonathan Frid. His theatre roots must have helped but he's a treat to watch in this part. What's important to note here is that the film and Frid's version is much darker than the portrayal on television. It's more sinister and violent and I think it may be another reason why the film did well. There were so many restrictions to what could be said, seen and shown on daytime television in those days that it's a marvel that Dark Shadows ever got on the air- let alone stayed there for its 5 year run. It's a tribute to the writers, the cast and Dan Curtis that it did. I think a great many of us watched this and said " they finally got to do it with style ".I can't say whether the younger generation will take to this (it's been ripped off so many times by other writers, television and film makers- and redone poorly,  they may feel like they're seeing something that's second hand) but trust me- if you looking for a good old fashioned vampire tale that has a story, has a really good central character with good supporting ones, and takes its time and then lets it rip, House of Dark Shadows is a good treat.Special note: Dan Curtis went on to make and direct the Kolchak Night Stalker and Night Strangler telefilms as well as Richard Matheson's Trilogy of Terror. He had a real knack for making nicely made, atmospheric nightmares that have inspired those of us who watch and write. This was his first big budget directorial debut and he showed a really good sense of visual story telling (along with Sam Hall who was also a mainstay on the original soap series), of mood and atmosphere (all huge in creating the reality of Collingswood). Robert Cobert's music always helped to set the mood and does so once again, here." Tell them it's Barnabas Collins calling ".

Watching now in 2012 was nostalgic bliss---I loved the original! reviewText: Several times a year and always on Halloween, I have to watch House of Dark Shadows. Released in 1970, it is based on the cult TV series Dark Shadows, which ran from 1966-1972. The Gothic series was filmed in black and white and focused on the eccentric and wealthy Collins family and their estate called Collinwood, which was located in, appropriately enough, the town of Collinsport, Maine.The movie (filmed in glorious color!) focuses on the point in the series where the family is visited by Barnabas Collins, an enigmatic man who says he's a relative from England. The modern day Collins family is shocked at how much Barnabas looks like their 19th century ancestor of the same name. What they don't know is that Barnabas IS that relative. He is a 175-year-old vampire haunted by guilt and, since being released from his coffin by a worker at Collinwood, unable to rest.The Collins clan lets him move into what's known as "The Old House" on the grounds of Collinwood. That's the mansion that the original Barnabas lived in more than a century prior. The place is a mess, having been allowed to fall into disrepair.Now that he's back, Barnabas can't control himself, and he ends up biting the neck of one of his relatives. This sets off a bad chain of events that eventually becomes Barnabas' undoing.Long story short, Barnabas meets and falls in love with a nanny living at Collinwood, Maggie Evans, who looks an awful lot like his lost 19th century love, Josette. Simultaneously, Dr. Julia Hoffman figures out that Barnabas is a vampire and thinks she has found a way to make him normal again. But in the process, she falls in love with him. A real supernatural Gothic love triangle, eh?What I love about the movie (beyond the dark, Gothic atmosphere) is that while Barnabas is an ambiguous figure, he is somewhat sentimental too. And while he's the villain, the viewer finds themselves rooting for him anyway. After all, he doesn't want to be a vampire and he really doesn't want to hurt anyone either.I won't tell you the ending in case you want to check out the movie. It really is well done for the time, and was directed by Dan Curtis, who not only directed the Dark Shadows TV series, but also another of my favorite movies, Burnt Offerings (1967).I have very fond memories of watching reruns of the TV series and movie late at night when I was a kid. My brother and I would watch it together, even though he was scared to death of the supernatural. We also liked that all of this took place right in our own New England, home of so many ghosts.

reviewText: I remember seeing House of Dark Shadows in a movie theater when I was about 9 years old, not long after it's first run at a very old theater that was the perfect setting to see this film. The theater was old and gothic looking, the perfect setting for this very moody atmospheric and rather gothic film version of the classic Dan Curtis daytime soap opera that was runing on daytime television at the time. Curtis I think suprised everyone with what turned out to be a rather bloody film that captured the very essence of the darkest qualities of the tv series. The production qualities are far better in this film version than those of the tv series as well. Of course next to Bela Lugosi and Christopher Lee, Jonathan Frid is my favorite vampire under those monumental actors.Frid captures both the charm and the menace of Barnabas Collins beautifully, both in the series and especially in this film. It was a sad day recently when it was announced that Frid has passed away, but though I've had a love\hate relationship with Tim Burton's version, I am glad it was made because clearly it was the main reason this film finally recieved both a dvd and Blu-Ray release. Which reminds me, I should mention that as of the time of this review the streaming version of this classic presented here on Amazon is pathetic. It literally appears as if it was transfered from a second generation vhs, so be aware of this. The Blu-Ray however is a wonderful transfer and the picture is as good as it get's for a film of this age. It's truly a fantastic celebration that this movie finally recieved a decent release, and certainly a whole new generation of younger viewers will finally get the opportunity to discover this rare gem. But please consider that the movie was released in the early 70's and you can't compare it to the full catelogue of vampire and horror films released over the past 40 years. It's classic gloomy and atmospheric 70's horror that is as good as it can get. Go in with expectations of this and you should feel like you've finally seen a truly great vampire film.

reviewText: Dan Curtis' 'House of Dark Shadows' (1970) is not a great film, but was a substantial commercial success upon release, and remains generally beloved by fans of the television series (1966-1971) upon which it was based.Produced as the series was winding down, 'House of Dark Shadows' magnifies and exaggerates the fantasy world depicted in the television series, rushes the characters through their paces, and then kills off half of them by the climax. As such, it stands on the edge between the pre-1960s monster/horror film, in which the hero always persevered, and the post-1970s horror film, in which the hero or protagonist was often overcome.For fans of the series, old and new, 'House of Dark Shadows' will be something of a time capsule and nostalgia piece. Overall, in terms of tone and style, the film stands somewhere between an average American-International horror film of the era, such as 'The Haunted Palace' (1963), and a typical 1960s Hammer film like 'Plague of the Zombies' (1966) or 'Frankenstein Must Be Destroyed' (1969).If 'House of Dark Shadows' is not a great film, it is certainly an adequate one, if episodic, weakly scripted, and rather rushed.The film would have benefitted from another twenty to thirty minutes to allow the characters to develop and the script to reflect more nuance and sophistication. Instead, the script jumps from set piece to set piece, relying on the audience's knowledge of the television series and general cinematic information about vampire lore to fill in the gaps.The touching scene in which Barnabas and Maggie stroll the grounds of Collinswood in the bright afternoon sunlight is a perfect example of the kind of nuance the rest of the film lacks. Several additional scenes reflecting the same sort of delicacy would have given the film a more rounded three-dimensional quality, which is important, since Barnabas is a Byronic anti-hero, both 'good' and 'bad,' both lover and predator.The plot, lifted straight from the television scripts, has vampire Barnabas Collins (Jonathan Frid) being accidentally freed from his grave after centuries of entombment and then posing as  his own modern-day descendent to the Collins family. Barnabas believes that lovely young governess Maggie Evans (Kathyrn Lee Scott) is the reincarnation of his own beloved Jossette, and sets about pursuing her.Assertive doctor Julia Hoffman (Grayson Hall) suspects the truth about Barnabas and comes to believe she can permanently cure him.Meanwhile, the bodies of viciously attacked women are piling up around Collinsport.There are many very good, if often brief, performances in 'House of Dark Shadows,' including John Karlen as troubled handyman Willie Loomis, Donald Briscoe as Todd Blake, and especially Nancy Barrett as Carolyn Stoddard; what makes the two former performances especially striking is that Karlen and Briscoe manage to create actual screen presence out of the fairly insubstantial material provided for their characters.'House of Dark Shadows,' however, belongs almost wholly to Nancy Barrett, who steals the film (as she stole the movie poster) as the spiteful, emotionally frustrated Carolyn (an interpretation of the character not present in the television series). Twice bitten by Barnabas, who merely uses her for her blood, she dies and rises from the grave, stalking her significantly younger cousin, David Collins (David Henesy) in the 'abandoned pool house' in the film's most intense, surreal, and memorable scene.Carolyn's later assault on boyfriend Todd, and her capture and staking in a dilapidated barn on the Collinswood grounds, is also highly suspenseful. Barrett portrays the vampiric Carolyn as equal parts ghost, succubus, vampire, and rabid animal. So multifaceted is Barrett's performance that the audience feels sympathy, even empathy, for the wild-eyed and raving Carolyn as she is held down by numerous male hands and staked through the heart, resisting violently to the very end.Other parts and performances are not as good by far: famous 'Golden Age of Cinema' actress Joan Bennett is simply given little to do but stand around as matriarch Elizabeth Stoddard Collins, and Grayson Hall, conversely, wildly overacts as the shifty-eyed, suspicious, and constantly plotting Dr. Hoffman.Jonathan Frid knew the part of Barnabas Collins thoroughly by 1971, and does as good a job as he is able throughout the film.'House of Dark Shadows' is, surprisingly, something of a literal bloodbath, with half the characters dead by its closing credits, a fact that certainly caught the television audience off guard in 1970 and certainly contributed to the film's commercial success. Bright red blood gushes towards the audience from necks, chests, and mouths in one scene after another.Another interesting, if not uniformly successful, aspect of the film is its use of the relatively small Lyndhurst mansion as the notorious Collinswood estate, and Tarrytown, also on the Hudson River, as Collinsport, which is supposed to exist on the wild, isolated, and rocky coast of Maine.'House of Dark Shadows' also puts the evocative Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, which abuts the Old Dutch Burial Ground made famous by Washington Irving in his famous tale, to good and moody use in several scenes, including Barnabas' awakening and Carolyn's funeral in torrential rain.'House of Dark Shadows' was followed by the far weaker 'Night of Dark Shadows' in 1971, which wisely dropped the Barnabas saga and took up a completely different plot thread concerning the vengeful ghost of Angelique (Lara Parker) and a modified version of the Quentin Collins character (David Selby). Many of the Curtis acting troupe, including John Karlen, Grayson Hall, Thayer David, and Nancy Barrett, returned in new roles.Curtis, who directed again, was unfortunately (and ironically) forced to cut some thirty-five minutes from 'Night of Dark Shadows' by the studio, making the resulting movie thin, incoherent, and dull.
